{{POV-check|date=October 2012}} {{POV|date=October 2012}} {{Quran}} '''Bakkah''' ({{lang-ar|بكة}}) is an ancient name for [[Mecca]], the most holy city of [[Islam]].{{cite book|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=XneTstDbcC0C&pg=PA342&dq=mecca+bakkah&hl=en&ei=P35NTraCNdKBhQeHosDiBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=mecca%20bakkah&f=false|page=342|title=Encyclopedic dictionary of archaeology|author=Barbara Ann Kipfer|edition=Illustrated|publisher=Springer|year=2000|ISBN=0-306-46158-7, 9780306461583}} Most people believe they are synonyms, but to Muslim scholars there is a distinction: Bakkah refers to the [[Kaaba]] and the sacred site immediately surrounding it, while Mecca is the name of the city in which they are both located.{{cite book|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=isDgI0-0Ip4C&pg=PA337&dq=mecca+becca&hl=en&ei=PYxOTqWKOo3csgb43-GxAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFEQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=mecca%20becca&f=false|page=337|title=The Qur'an: an encyclopedia|author=Oliver Leaman|edition=Illustrated, annotated, reprint|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=2006|ISBN=0-415-32639-7, 9780415326391}} Bakkah is mentioned in ''[[sura]]'' 3 ([[Al-i-Imran]]), ''[[ayah]]'' 96 of the [[Qur'an]], where it is said to be the site of the first place of worship. Others also identify it with the [[Bible|Biblical]] "valley of Baca" from [[Psalms]] 84 ({{lang-he|בך}}).{{bibleverse||Psalms|84:6|KJV}}, [[Authorized King James Version|King James Version]] ==Bakkah and Mecca== Bakkah (also transliterated ''Baca'', ''Baka'', 'Bakke',''Bakah'', ''[[Bakka, Lebanon|Bakka]]'', ''Becca'', ''Bekka'', etc.) is the ancient name for the site of Mecca.{{cite book|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=uRGoSE8AFAAC&pg=PA85&dq=mecca+becca&hl=en&ei=55ZOTvmSI8aUswaMt7SjAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=mecca%20becca&f=false|page=85|title=Muhammad and Jesus: a comparison of the prophets and their teachings|author=William E. Phipps|edition=Illustrated|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|year=1999|ISBN=0-8264-1207-6, 9780826412072}}{{cite book|page=174|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=fTFz8BC2G0MC&pg=PA174&dq=macca+bacca&hl=en&ei=8NZOTrCjMZTD8QPI3r2nBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBDgU#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Nasir Khusraw, the ruby of Badakhshan: a portrait of the Persian poet, traveller and philosopher|author=Alice C. Hunsberger|edition=Illustrated|publisher=I.B.Tauris|year=2000|ISBN=1-85043-919-2, 9781850439196}} An [[Arabic language]] word, its [[etymology]], like that of Mecca, is obscure.{{cite book|page=513|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=OWQOAQAAMAAJ&q=bakka+%22etymologically+obscure%22&dq=bakka+%22etymologically+obscure%22&hl=en&ei=nSBRTsC3LI774QS5uOi-Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA|title=Encyclopedia of Arabic language and linguistics, Volume 4|author=Kees Versteegh|editor=C. H. M. Versteegh and Kees Versteegh|edition=Illustrated|publisher=Brill|year=2008|ISBN=90-04-14476-5, 9789004144767}} One meaning ascribed to it is "narrow," seen as descriptive of the area in which the valley of the holy places and the city of Mecca are located, pressed in upon as they are by mountains.{{cite book|page=302|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=focLrox-frUC&pg=PA302&dq=mecca+bakkah&hl=en&ei=An5NTvngBoyGhQfexZHjBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFUQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=mecca%20bakkah&f=false|title=The new encyclopedia of Islam|author=Cyril Glassé and Huston Smith|edition=Revised, illustrated|publisher=Rowman Altamira|year=2003|ISBN=0-7591-0190-6, 9780759101906}} Widely believed to be a synonym for Mecca, it is said to be more specifically the early name for the valley located therein, while Muslim scholars generally use it to refer to the sacred area of the city that immediately surrounds and includes the [[Kaaba]].{{cite book|pages=22–25|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=9zpbEj0xA_sC&pg=PA47&dq=mecca+becca&hl=en&ei=CsVOTsHYLcTEswbJ7YmTAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBzg8#v=onepage&q=becca&f=false|title=Muhammad, prophet of God|author=Daniel C. Peterson|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|year=2007|ISBN=0-8028-0754-2, 9780802807540}}{{cite book|title=The Holy Quran with English Translation|author=Sher Ali Maulawi, Mirza Tahir, Ahmad Hadhrat|publisher=Islam International|year=2004|ISBN=1-85372-779-2, 9781853727795|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=8hCktJb64WIC&pg=PA753&dq=mecca+becca&hl=en&ei=LaVOTrL6M43XsgbL7MCfAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAzge#v=onepage&q=mecca%20becca&f=false|page=753}} The form Bakkah is used for the name Mecca in the Quran in 3:96, while the form Mecca is used in 48:24.{{cite book|page=6|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=9niSNOCIoL8C&pg=PA25&dq=mecca+bakkah&hl=en&ei=pIBNTrPOCciz8QPNvazBBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBTgU#v=onepage&q=bakkah&f=false|title=Capital cities of Arab Islam|author=Philip Khûri Hitti|edition=Illustrated|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|year=1973|ISBN=0-8166-0663-3, 9780816606634}} In [[Old South Arabian|South Arabic]], the language in use in the southern portion of the [[Arabian Peninsula]] at the time of [[Muhammad]], the ''b'' and ''m'' were interchangeable. The Quranic passage using the form Bakkah says: "The first sanctuary appointed for mankind was that at Bakkah, a blessed place, a guidance for the peoples."{{Cite quran|3|96|e=97|s=ns}}: {{Quote|The first House (of worship) appointed for men was that at Bakka: Full of blessing and of guidance for all kinds of beings:
In it are Signs Manifest; (for example), the Station of Abraham; whoever enters it attains security; [[Pilgrimage]] thereto is a duty men owe to [[Allah]],- those who can afford the journey; but if any deny faith, Allah stands not in need of any of His creatures.|Qur'an, sura 3 (Al-i-Imran), ayat 96-97}} Other references to Mecca in the Quran (6:92, 42:5) call it ''Umm al-Qura'', meaning "mother of all settlements." In Islamic tradition, Bakkah is where [[Hagar]] and [[Ishmael]] ([[Islamic view of Ishmael|Ismā'īl]]) settled after being taken by [[Abraham]] ([[Islamic view of Abraham|Ibrāhīm]]) to the wilderness, a story related in the Bible's [[Book of Genesis]] (21:14-21).{{bibleverse||Genesis|21:14-21:21|KJV}} Genesis tells of how after Hagar and Ishmael ran out of water to drink. In Arab tradition, Hagar runs back and forth between two elevated points seven times to search for help before sitting down in despair, at which point the angel speaks as recorded in Genesis 21:17-19: {{quote|God heard the cry of the boy, and an angel of God called to Hagar from heaven and said to her, 'What troubles you, Hagar? Fear not, for God has heeded the cry of the boy where he is. Come, lift up the boy and hold him by the hand, for I will make a great nation of him.' Then God opened her eyes and she saw a well of water. She went and filled the skin with water and let the boy drink.}} Here, the tradition holds that a spring gushed forth from the spot where Hagar had laid Ishmael, and this spring came to be known as the [[Well of Zamzam]]. When Muslims on [[hajj]] run between the hills of [[Safa and Marwah]] seven times, it is to commemorate Hagar's search for help and the resulting revelation of the well of Zamzam. It is also believed that Hagar and Ishamel settled in Bakkah, and the Quran relates that Abraham came to Mecca to help his son Ishmael build the Kaaba adjacent to the well of Zamzam. [[Ibn Ishaq]], the 8th century Arab Muslim historian, relates that during the renovation of Kaaba undertaken by Muhammad, the prophet of Islam, in 605 CE, the [[Quraysh]] found an inscription in one of the corners of the foundation of the building that mentions Bakkah. Composed in [[Syriac language|Syriac]], it was incomprehensible to the Quraysh until a Jew translated it for them as follows: "I am Allah, the Lord of Bakka. I created it on the day I created heaven and earth and formed the sun and the moon, and I surrounded it with seven pious angels. It will stand while its two mountains stand, a blessing to its people with milk and water."{{cite book|page=47|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=EK5MqskDYC0C&pg=PA47&dq=bakka+syriac&hl=en&ei=t1RPTuyeIcuy8QPrk6y0Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBjgU#v=onepage&q=bakka%20syriac&f=false|title= The Hajj: the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca and the holy places|author=F. E. Peters|edition=Reprint, illustrated|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=1995|ISBN=0-691-02619-X, 9780691026190}} The name Bakkah is woven into the [[kiswa]], the cloth covering the Kaaba that is replaced each year before the [[Hajj]].{{cite book|page=536|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=pGdUQ7urj6IC&pg=PA536&dq=bakah+mecca&hl=en&ei=fs5QTqKuGNDU4QTxr4ntBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwADge#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Short studies in the science of comparative religions: embracing all the religions of Asia|author=James George Roche Forlong|edition=Reprint|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|year=1897|ISBN=0-7661-0157-6, 9780766101579}} ==Valley of Baca== {{Synthesis|article|date=October 2012}} The Valley of Baca is mentioned in Psalm 84 of the Bible in the following passage: {{quote|How lovely is Your dwelling-place, O Lord of Hosts. I long, I yearn for the courts of the Lord; my body and soul shout for joy to the living God ... Happy are those who dwell in Your house; they forever praise You. Happy is the man who finds refuge in You, whose mind is on the [pilgrim] highways. They pass through the Valley of Baca, regarding it as a place of springs, as if the early rain had covered it with blessing ... Better one day in Your courts than a thousand [anywhere else]; I would rather stand at the threshold of God's house than dwell in the tents of the wicked}} The original [[Hebrew language]] phrase for the Valley of Baca is ''emeq ha-Baka''.{{cite book|page=235|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=f0qEoKILVS4C&pg=PA235&dq=%22ha+baka%22&hl=en&ei=NTNRTtXFG-TP4QSR4bSaAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGEQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=%22ha%20baka%22&f=false|title=At the interface of prosody and structural analysis, Volume 2|author=Jan P. Fokkelman|publisher=Uitgeverij Van Gorcum|year=2000|ISBN=90-232-3381-6, 9789023233817}}{{cite book|page=186|url=http://books.google.ca/books?id=3zMmA-6IDUcC&pg=PA186&dq=%22ha+baka%22&hl=en&ei=UTNRTquXA-nE4gSM9KnaBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDAQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=%22ha%20baka%22&f=false|title=Islam, Judaism, and Christianity: theological and historical affiliations|author=Heribert Busse|edition=Illustrated|publisher=Markus Wiener Publishers|year=1998|ISBN=1-55876-144-6, 9781558761445}}{{bibleverse||Psalms|84:1-84:6|KJV}} of the King James Version reads: {{Quote|How amiable are thy tabernacles, O LORD of hosts!
My soul longeth, yea, even fainteth for the courts of the LORD: my heart and my flesh crieth out for the living God.
Yea, the sparrow hath found an house, and the swallow a nest for herself, where she may lay her young, even thine altars, O LORD of hosts, my King, and my God.
Blessed are they that dwell in thy house: they will be still praising thee. [[Selah]].
Blessed is the man whose strength is in thee; in whose heart are the ways of them.
Who passing through the valley of Baca make it a well; the rain also filleth the pools.}} It can also be translated as "Valley of the Balsam Tree" or "Valley of the Weeper". This otherwise unidentified valley has been connected to Bakkah by Islamic writers. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Islam}} *[http://www.islamic-awareness.org/History/kaaba.html Mecca & Baca Islamic site ] [[Category:Christianity and Islam]] [[Category:Islam and other religions]] [[Category:Quranic places]] [[Category:Psalms]] [[dv:ބައްކާ]]
